Founded in 1962, COI

M specializes in polycondensation, polyaddition (polyurethane) products and many other chemical specialties.  The quality, variety and extensive nature of its products range, makes Coim one of the major producers in its field.</w:t></w:r><w:r><w:br/></w:r><w:r><w:br/><w:t>Coim operates worldwide through a network of manufacturing sites, sales offices and agencies. Its workforce is dedicated to support guarantee of quality and service, ensuring flexibility and efficiency necessary from an important global industrial organization.</w:t></w:r></w:p><w:p/><w:p><w:pPr><w:rPr><w:u w:val="single"/></w:rPr></w:pPr><w:r><w:rPr><w:u w:val="single"/></w:rPr><w:t>Regulatory Overview</w:t></w:r></w:p><w:p/><w:p><w:r><w:t>The covered process is subject to the New Jersey Toxic Catastrophe Prevention Act (TCPA) (same as EPA Risk Management Program) as well as OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) due to the presence of flammable materials in the process.  Other major </w:t></w:r><st1:State w:st="on"><st1:place w:st="on"><w:r><w:t>New Jersey</w:t></w:r></st1:place></st1:State><w:r><w:t> regulatory programs that affect the overall site include:  Discharge Prevention Control and Countermeasures (DPCC) Plan, Stormwater Pollution Prevention Plan (SPPP), and air permitting.</w:t></w:r></w:p><w:p/><w:p><w:pPr><w:pStyle w:val="DefaultText"/><w:rPr><w:u w:val="single"/></w:rPr></w:pPr><w:r><w:rPr><w:u w:val="single"/></w:rPr><w:t>Covered Process Overview</w:t></w:r></w:p><w:p><w:pPr><w:pStyle w:val="DefaultText"/></w:pPr></w:p><w:p><w:pPr><w:pStyle w:val="DefaultText"/></w:pPr><w:r><w:t>The basic process is to make a polyurethane </w:t></w:r><w:r><w:rPr><w:u w:val="single"/></w:rPr><w:t>adhesive or elastomer product</w:t></w:r><w:r><w:t>.  The basic chemistry is as follows:</w:t></w:r></w:p><w:p><w:pPr><w:pStyle w:val="DefaultText"/></w:pPr></w:p><w:p><w:pPr><w:pStyle w:val="DefaultText"/></w:pPr><w:r><w:tab wx:wTab="720" wx:tlc="none" wx:cTlc="11"/></w:r><w:r><w:tab wx:wTab="720" wx:tlc="no

ne" wx:cTlc="11"/><w:t>Polyols + Isocyanate = Polyurethane Elastomer or Adhesive</w:t></w:r></w:p><w:p><w:pPr><w:pStyle w:val="DefaultText"/><w:rPr><w:u w:val="single"/></w:rPr></w:pPr></w:p><w:p><w:pPr><w:pStyle w:val="DefaultText"/></w:pPr><w:r><w:t>Various temperatures, processing times and trace ingredients will vary the final component mix and specifications.  Ethyl Acetate will be used in the adhesive formulations as an added process ingredient.  </w:t></w:r></w:p><w:p><w:pPr><w:pStyle w:val="DefaultText"/></w:pPr></w:p><w:p><w:pPr><w:pStyle w:val="DefaultText"/></w:pPr><w:r><w:t>The name </w:t></w:r><w:r><w:rPr><w:b-cs/></w:rPr><w:t>Polyols</w:t></w:r><w:r><w:t> refers to </w:t></w:r><w:hlink w:dest="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chemical_compound" w:screenTip="Chemical compound"><w:r><w:rPr><w:rStyle w:val="Hyperlink"/><w:color w:val="auto"/></w:rPr><w:t>chemical compounds</w:t></w:r></w:hlink><w:r><w:t> containing multiple </w:t></w:r><w:hlink w:dest="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hydroxyl" w:screenTip="Hydroxyl"><w:r><w:rPr><w:rStyle w:val="Hyperlink"/><w:color w:val="auto"/></w:rPr><w:t>hydroxyl</w:t></w:r></w:hlink><w:r><w:t> groups such as Ethylene Glycol.  Various blends of 2, 4 and 2, 6 isomers of Toluene Diisocyanate (TDI) are used in the production of adhesives. The reactive ingredients in a typical system with TDI are hydroxyl-terminated Polyols. The process is mildly exothermic.  Higher temperatures will cause product quality failure and not a safety issue. </w:t></w:r></w:p><w:p><w:pPr><w:pStyle w:val="DefaultText"/></w:pPr></w:p><w:p><w:pPr><w:pStyle w:val="DefaultText"/></w:pPr><w:r><w:t>The origin of polyurethane dates back to the beginning of World War II where it is was first developed as a replacement for rubber. The versatility of this new organic polymer and its ability to substitute for scarce materials, spurred numerous applications. During World War II, polyurethane coatings were used for the impregnation of paper and the manufacture of

airplane finishes and corrosion resistant coatings to protect metal, wood and masonry. </w:t></w:r></w:p><w:p><w:pPr><w:pStyle w:val="NormalWeb"/></w:pPr><w:r><w:t>By the end of the war, polyurethane coatings were being manufactured and used on an industrial scale and could be custom formulated for specific applications. By the mid-50â¿¿s, polyurethanes could be found in coatings and adhesives, elastomers and rigid foams. It was not until the late 1950â¿¿s, that comfortable cushioning flexible foams were commercially available. With the development of a low-cost polyether polyol, flexible foams opened the door to the upholstery and automotive applications we know today. </w:t></w:r></w:p><w:p><w:pPr><w:pStyle w:val="NormalWeb"/></w:pPr><w:r><w:t>Formulations, additives and processing techniques continued to be developed such as reinforced and structural moldings for exterior automotive parts and one-component systems. Today, polyurethanes can be found in virtually everything we touch â¿¿ our desks, chairs, cars, clothes, footwear, appliances, beds, and the insulation in our walls, roof and moldings on our homes. </w:t></w:r></w:p><w:p><w:pPr><w:tabs><w:tab w:val="left" w:pos="0"/><w:tab w:val="left" w:pos="1440"/><w:tab w:val="left" w:pos="2160"/><w:tab w:val="left" w:pos="2880"/><w:tab w:val="left" w:pos="3600"/><w:tab w:val="left" w:pos="4320"/><w:tab w:val="left" w:pos="5040"/><w:tab w:val="left" w:pos="5760"/><w:tab w:val="left" w:pos="6480"/><w:tab w:val="left" w:pos="7200"/><w:tab w:val="left" w:pos="7920"/><w:tab w:val="left" w:pos="8640"/><w:tab w:val="left" w:pos="9360"/></w:tabs><w:suppressAutoHyphens/><w:spacing w:line="240" w:line-rule="at-least"/></w:pPr><w:r><w:t>An Inherently Safer Technology (IST) review was done for these processes.
